node.text:
18-year-old Palak Kohli is an international para-athlete representing India at badminton in Tokyo 2020.

She only took up the sport in 2017, but was winning world titles by 2019.

#Paralympics #Badminton #BBCNews

node.title: ‘I turned my disability into a super-ability’

node.text:
Small numbers of Afghans have marked the country's Independence Day by taking to the streets waving their black, red and green national flag, in protest against the Taliban's takeover of the country.

The militants have been replacing the national flag with their own white one. 

#BBCNews

node.title: Protesters wave Afghanistan national flag at Independence Day protests

node.text:
A child has been filmed as she was handed over the wall to a US soldier at Kabul airport.

There has been chaos as Afghans continue with their attempts to escape from the Taliban.

Taliban fighters have also fired in the air, and US soldiers have used tear gas to control the crowds of people.

Tap the link in our bio for more on the situation in the country.

#Afghanistan #BBCNews

node.title: Afghan child passed over wall as chaos continues at Kabul airport

node.text:
You shall go the ball! 

Sir Andrew Lloyd Webber's Cinderella is finally opening in the West End.

The show had been scheduled to open last year but was delayed by the Covid pandemic meant  Andrew Lloyd Webber’s Cinderella is only now ready to go to the ball.

The tale has been made more relevant for today’s audiences by Killing Eve and Promising Young Woman writer Emerald Fennell.

The BBC spoke to both Fennell and Lloyd Webber and also to star Carrie Hope Fletcher just ahead of the show’s press night.The show's star, Carrie Hope Fletcher, who plays Cinderella in the production says the cast "cannot wait to get in front of that full capacity audience."

node.title: Cinderella finally opens in London's West End

node.text:
“British soldiers were my brothers.”

An Afghan interpreter who worked alongside the British army has pleaded with the UK Prime Minister to evacuate him and his family from Afghanistan.

Ahmed (not his real name) had received permission to travel to the UK last week, but a day later the Taliban seized control of the capital, Kabul.

He now fears for his safety and has requested a "pathway to safety" from the UK government and says "everyone who worked with coalition forces need to be relocated as soon as possible."

Tap the link in our bio to read more about his plight in the wake of the Taliban’s takeover of Afghanistan.

#Afghanistan #Kabul #BBCNews

node.title: Afghan interpreter who worked for UK begs PM for help

node.text:
Wildfires have spread across Europe as many countries experience extreme heatwaves.

While these fires have a natural role to play in the ecological cycle, climate change means they may be more likely and severe.

The fires are not just being seen in Europe - countries like the US, Israel and Algeria have also battled with out-of-control blazes.

#Wildfires #BBCNews

node.title: Wildfires rage across parts of Europe

node.text:
A new campaign, WeThe15, has been launched to improve the lives of disabled people, who make up 15% of the world’s population. 

Described as a “game-changer”, it aims to to raise awareness, improve inclusion and end discrimination of disabled people around the world.

“Awareness needs to go down every day - not just like, ‘we’ve had the Paralympics, very good’, and then go back to wherever they think we go.”

Tap the link in our bio to learn more about the campaign, which is being launched ahead of the Tokyo Paralympic Games. 

#Paralympics #Tokyo2020 #BBCNews

node.title: Can the Paralympics bring lasting change?

node.text:
“With infrared, even if it was so smokey you couldn’t see your hand in front of your face, it would still look crystal clear.”

Planes equipped with infrared scanners are helping authorities take on historic wildfires in the US.

Their ability to see through thick haze allows firefighters to get an accurate picture of the fire’s behaviour from the air.

#Wildfires #BBCNews

node.title: Using technology in the air to battle fires on the ground

node.text:
Thomas Yates has become "addicted" to litter picking.

He has collected more than 2,800 abandoned face masks while out running and cycling and used them to create artwork.

The 45-year-old was made redundant at the start of the coronavirus pandemic and has used his extra free time clearing the streets of "disgraceful" litter.

"It just shows you can make something from a load of crap on the side of the road."

#BBCNews

node.title: Making art out of disposed face masks

node.text:
"Today it looks like normal."

Female presenters are back on TV at a major Afghan news outlet, after briefly being taken off air as the Taliban took over Afghanistan.

Tolo News' Siyar Sirat said: "We have normal resources at the office, we have women on screen."

It comes as questions are asked over how women's rights will look under Taliban rule. 

The Taliban have given assurances that their rights will be respected according to Islamic law. 

Tap the link in our bio to find out more.

#Afghanistan #BBCNews

node.title: Female presenters return to TV in Afghanistan

node.text:
“I think I’m just shocked that it has gotten so bad, so fast.”

Photojournalist Justin Sullivan has been following California's second-largest reservoir's declining water levels since 2014.

Sullivan, who works for Getty Images, has been witnessing first-hand the climate's impact on Lake Oroville through his lens.

He says he is shocked at how fast the water is disappearing from one of California's most important water sources.

#California #LakeOroville #Environment #Water #Sustainability #BBCNews

node.title: Images show dramatic decline of California's 'life source'

node.text:
This is the dramatic moment a police officer and bystander rescued a man who had lost consciousness and fallen onto subway tracks in New York, moments before train pulled into the station.

 
#NewYork #BBCNews

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by BBC News on August 20, 2021. May be an image of 3 people, people standing and text that says 'BBC NEWS'.

node.text:
This is the moment a baby was handed over to US soldiers at Kabul airport.
 
As thousands of Afghan citizens and foreign nationals attempt to flee the Taliban, scenes there have become increasingly desperate.
 
Afghanistan's capital airport has become the only way out of the country for many, as the Taliban has closed land border crossings.

Inside the walls of the airport compound, more than 4,000 US troops are in temporary control. Outside, heavily-armed Taliban fighters now ring the perimeter, generating an atmosphere of fear.

Click the link in our bio to read more about the dangers Afghans are facing trying to reach the airport. 

(📸: Reuters)

#Afghanistan #Taliban #BBCNews

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by BBC News on August 20, 2021. May be an image of text.

node.text:
Subscription site OnlyFans has announced it will block sexually explicit photos and videos from 1 October.

The London-based social media site enables people to post nude videos and photos and charge subscribers for tips or a monthly fee.

Creators can post a range of content from cooking to fitness videos, but it is best known for pornography.

Click the link in our bio to find out why they are making the change and what will still be allowed.

(📸:Reuters)
 
#OnlyFans #BBCNews

node.text:
18-year-old Palak Kohli is an international para-athlete representing India at badminton in Tokyo 2020.

She only took up the sport in 2017, but was winning world titles by 2019.

#Paralympics #Badminton #BBCNews

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by BBC News on August 19, 2021. May be an image of ‎1 person and ‎text that says '‎BBC NEWS حدم nology Taliban carrying out 'door-to-door' manhunt‎'‎‎.

node.text:
The Taliban have stepped up their search for people who worked for Nato forces or the previous Afghan government, a UN document has warned.

It said the militants have been going door-to-door to find targets and threatening their family members.

The hardline Islamist group has tried to reassure Afghans since seizing power, promising there would be "no revenge". But there are fears the Taliban have changed little since the brutal 1990s.

"There are a high number of individuals that are currently being targeted by the Taliban and the threat is crystal clear," Christian Nellemann, who heads the group behind the report, told the BBC.

He warned that anyone on the Taliban's blacklist was in severe danger, and that there could be mass executions.

Tap the link in our bio for more on this story. 
 
(📸: Getty Images)

#Afghanistan #BBCNews

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by BBC News on August 19, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'BBNES NEWS Anger as Nicole Kidman reportedly enters Hong Kong quarantine-free'.

node.text:
Australian actress Nicole Kidman’s arrival in Hong Kong sparked widespread anger after she was reportedly spotted out and about two days after touching down.

The city has some of the strictest Covid rules in place, with up to 21 days' quarantine required.

She is in Hong Kong to film a new show about the lives of wealthy, glamorous expats - already a source of tension as locals contend with increasing restrictions under the new national security law.

In response to questions about "overseas film personnel" and quarantine, the Commerce and Economic Development Bureau said that restrictions are waived "to carry out designated professional work".

On social media, several people pointed out they have not been able to see family for months thanks to the restrictions.

Tap the link in our bio for more reactions to the controversy.
 
(📸: Getty Images)

#HongKong #Quarantine #BBCNews

node.text:
Small numbers of Afghans have marked the country's Independence Day by taking to the streets waving their black, red and green national flag, in protest against the Taliban's takeover of the country.

The militants have been replacing the national flag with their own white one. 

#BBCNews

node.text:
A child has been filmed as she was handed over the wall to a US soldier at Kabul airport.

There has been chaos as Afghans continue with their attempts to escape from the Taliban.

Taliban fighters have also fired in the air, and US soldiers have used tear gas to control the crowds of people.

Tap the link in our bio for more on the situation in the country.

#Afghanistan #BBCNews

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by BBC News on August 19, 2021. May be an image of 1 person, outdoors and text that says 'BBCNES KN NGI NGT FLYG Zarauth Teenager sets off on attempt to become youngest gest woman to fly solo around the world'.

node.text:
19-year-old pilot Zara Rutherford has set off from Belgium on an attempt to become the youngest woman to fly solo around the world - flying over 52 countries and across the equator twice during her trip.
 
The circumnavigation includes 70 planned stops with 19 rest days and is due to conclude back in Kortijk on 4 November.

Miss Rutherford, who lives in Belgium, said the "greatest challenge" would be remote places like northern Russia or Greenland.

"There aren't many people who live there so if anything were to go wrong I would be in a bit of an awkward situation," she said.

Tap the link in our bio for more on her incredible journey.

(📷 Reuters)

#Pilot #WorldRecord #Flight #BBCNews

node.text:
You shall go the ball! 

Sir Andrew Lloyd Webber's Cinderella is finally opening in the West End.

The show had been scheduled to open last year but was delayed by the Covid pandemic meant  Andrew Lloyd Webber’s Cinderella is only now ready to go to the ball.

The tale has been made more relevant for today’s audiences by Killing Eve and Promising Young Woman writer Emerald Fennell.

The BBC spoke to both Fennell and Lloyd Webber and also to star Carrie Hope Fletcher just ahead of the show’s press night.The show's star, Carrie Hope Fletcher, who plays Cinderella in the production says the cast "cannot wait to get in front of that full capacity audience."

node.text:
“British soldiers were my brothers.”

An Afghan interpreter who worked alongside the British army has pleaded with the UK Prime Minister to evacuate him and his family from Afghanistan.

Ahmed (not his real name) had received permission to travel to the UK last week, but a day later the Taliban seized control of the capital, Kabul.

He now fears for his safety and has requested a "pathway to safety" from the UK government and says "everyone who worked with coalition forces need to be relocated as soon as possible."

Tap the link in our bio to read more about his plight in the wake of the Taliban’s takeover of Afghanistan.

#Afghanistan #Kabul #BBCNews

node.text:
Wildfires have spread across Europe as many countries experience extreme heatwaves.

While these fires have a natural role to play in the ecological cycle, climate change means they may be more likely and severe.

The fires are not just being seen in Europe - countries like the US, Israel and Algeria have also battled with out-of-control blazes.

#Wildfires #BBCNews
